results.title: Bush Mechanics: Episode 4: The Rainmakers
results.creator_credit: David Batty, Francis Jupurrula Kelly, Jennifer McMahon, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Film Australia and Warlpiri Media
results.brief_description: The ‘Bush Mechanics’ comprise a group of five young Warlpiri men from Yuendumu in the Northern Territory who can face any challenge when it comes to fixing cars, no matter what condition the car may be in! They will use the bush as a resource for spare parts and do whatever it takes to keep a car on the road. Their inventiveness, wonderfully offbeat humour and crazy antics, provide an insight into both contemporary and traditional Aboriginal culture. In the style of a road movie, the ‘Bush Mechanics’ series follows the men across the central desert, through their many mechanical mishaps, challenges and exploits. In Episode 4, these involve covering thousands of kilometres across the west to Broome to search for pearl shells for the rainmaker. The Bush Mechanics are: Simeon Jupurrula Ross, Steven Jupurrula Morton, Errol Jupurrula Nelson, Junior Jupurrula Wilson and Randall Jupurrula Wilson. Also features Jack Jakamurra Ross, and Francis Jupurrula Kelly. In English and Warlpiri with English subtitles.

results.title: Free Climbing
results.brief_description:
Rock climbing is a recreation for some, an obsession for others. “Free Climbing” was filmed at Mt Arapiles and Mt Buffalo and features hair-raising shots as climbers demonstrate safety and technical skills.

Since this work was made (in 1986) there have been significant rediscoveries of indigenous cultural heritage around Mt Arapiles (2019 - 2022). Some of the climbing areas pictured may no longer be accessible due to measures to protect this heritage.

results.title: Fashions for Men
results.creator_credit: Mel F. Nichols, Winifred Lade, Department of Information, Frank Coffey and John Maynard
results.brief_description: Produced by the Department of Information, this government propaganda film shows the manufacture of uniforms in factories for the Australian armed forces serving in the Second World War. The film begins with an opening sequence that chronicles the development of Australia’s armed forces since colonisation in 1788, showing the styles of uniform worn over the decades by soldiers making “glorious history”. The film then explores the mass production and assembly lines of the various equipment required for contemporary uniforms including silk parachutes, khaki wool clothing, brass badges, tin and felt hats, and gas masks. The film is a fascinating insight into factory production of the period, and an example of propaganda encouraging patriotic values in support of Australia’s armed forces. As with many instructional films of the period, the film reflects now outdated gender stereotypes, showing women working in assembly lines sewing on buttons, while men work with steel machinery.

results.title: Flying menace
results.creator_credit: W. H. Shepherd, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Describes the life cycle of the fruit fly, and the destruction it causes among Australian fruit. Illustrates the precautions being taken by the Department of Agriculture in checking the spread of the menace and shows how farmers should destroy contaminated fruit.

results.title: Born in the sun
results.creator_credit: John Heyer and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Shows the development of the dried fruits industry at Mildura from the time of Deakin’s irrigation bill, and highlights the part irrigation has played. Includes a dramatised extract of an Alfred Deakin speech. The film shows climatic setbacks which the industry has experienced. Illustrates the harvesting, processing and distribution of the fruit.

results.title: Farm Machinery Maintenance
results.creator_credit: Neville Bletcher, Eric Thompson, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Solarchrome
results.brief_description: ‘Farm Machinery Maintenance’ is an instructional film made for the Commonwealth Department of Primary Industry, designed for an audience of farmers and agricultural workers. The film’s narrator outlines the importance of maintaining farm machinery and equipment to ensure their function and longevity. The film offers an interesting insight into farming methods of the 1950s, with footage of rural farms, machines and tools. As with many educational films of the era, the film displays a (now outdated) gender division of stereotypical roles for men and for women, with men operating the heavy machinery while women serve tea and pick fruit.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Neville Bletcher, Eric Thompson, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Solarchrome

results.title: Ka Rorn: southern village
results.creator_credit: Arch Nicholson, John Morris, Thanom Soongnarata and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Our Asian Neighbours: Thailand”.
At 3am the village of Ka Rorn comes to life and work begins. Produce must be taken to market in Phuket, the only major town on the island. Ka Rorn is a tight, relaxed, self-sufficient community of about 30 families. The people grow coconuts and fruit to sell in the market but, being an island village, fishing is the most lucrative industry.

results.title: Disco
results.creator_credit: Phil Noyce, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Growing Up”.
This film considers social and sexual expectations and attitudes of teenagers attending a disco. Their perceptions of male and female roles, the similarities and differences are portrayed through their behaviour, conversation and dress. Cinematography by Mike Edols.

results.title: Thirst
results.creator_credit: Graham Chase, Robin Hughes and Film Australia
results.brief_description: One of three films as part of the National Drug Education Program which take an in-depth view of drug addiction in the day-to-day lives of ordinary people. Bob, a travelling salesman in children’s wear is an alcoholic. Although his is a loving family, his drinking and gambling cause his wife great stress and anguish. His drinking leaves him with little or nothing for housekeeping and expenses as he often “drinks” away his wages. Bob wants to lead a normal life and “tomorrow he’ll be sober”, but for him, tomorrow never comes. Photography by Dean Semler. (See also “All in the same boat” T/C 012758 and “Hassles” T/C 012851).

results.title: Brett and friends stick to a job: Brett and Greg
results.brief_description: This tape contains two programs entitled “Brett and Friends - Why stick to a job?” and “Brett and Greg - what are the options?” Brett and friends sets the context for Brett and Greg and should be viewed first. The two programs represent the viewpoints of Brett and Greg and their friends, some of whom had been unemployed for several months at the time of taping
